sn1.34:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, several glorious deities of the host of a hundred felicities, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

sn1.34:1.3.eng: Standing to one side, one deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.34:2.1.eng: “Among mankind there are no sensual pleasures that are permanent.

sn1.34:2.2.eng: Here there are sensuous things, bound to which,

sn1.34:2.3.eng: drunk on which, there’s no coming back.

sn1.34:2.4.eng: That person doesn’t return from Death’s dominion.”
sn1.34:2.4.comm: The deity seems to be expressing the non-Buddhist view that, while sensual pleasures in this realm are impermanent, the sinner goes to the realm of death from there is no return.

sn1.34:3.1.eng: “Gloom is born of desire; suffering is born of desire;
sn1.34:3.1.comm: These lines do not appear to be verse. The text marks them as a different speaker, but the identity of the speaker is unclear.

sn1.34:3.3.eng: when gloom is removed, suffering is removed.”

sn1.34:4.1.eng: “The world’s pretty things aren’t sensual pleasures.

sn1.34:4.2.eng: Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.

sn1.34:4.3.eng: The world’s pretty things stay just as they are,

sn1.34:4.4.eng: but the attentive remove desire for them.

sn1.34:5.1.eng: Give up anger, get rid of conceit,

sn1.34:5.2.eng: and get past all the fetters.

sn1.34:5.3.eng: Sufferings don’t torment the one who has nothing,

sn1.34:5.4.eng: not clinging to name and form.

sn1.34:6.1.eng: They gave up judgement without falling into conceit;

sn1.34:6.2.eng: craving for name and form was cut off right here.

sn1.34:6.3.eng: They cut the ties, untroubled, <j>with no need for hope.

sn1.34:6.5.eng: in this life or the next, they never find them,

sn1.34:6.6.eng: not in heaven nor in any abode.”

sn1.35:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, several glorious deities of the host of the fault-finders, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, and stood in the air.
sn1.35:1.2.comm: For the deities to stand in the air is disrespectful if not downright threatening (DN 3:1.21.1.).

sn1.35:2.2.eng: to be other than they really are,

sn1.35:3.2.eng: you shouldn’t say what you wouldn’t do.

sn1.35:6.1.pli: Atha kho tā devatāyo pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhahitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn1.35:6.1.eng: Then those deities landed on the ground, bowed with their heads at the Buddha’s feet and said,

sn1.35:6.2.pli: “accayo no, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yā mayaṃ bhagavantaṃ āsādetabbaṃ amaññimhā.
sn1.35:6.2.eng: “We made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of us to presume to attack the Buddha!

sn1.35:6.3.pli: Tāsaṃ no, bhante, bhagavā accayaṃ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṃ saṃvarāyā”ti.
sn1.35:6.3.eng: Please, sir, accept our mistake for what it is, so we will restrain ourselves in future.”

sn1.35:6.4.comm: The texts usually mention the Buddha smiling when he arrives at some place of special, hidden significance (MN 81:2.1, MN 83:2.1, AN 5.180:1.3). However, at Thag 12.2:11.1 he smiled when Sunīta, having gone forth from a low-born family, was honored by the gods. In both cases the Buddha smiled at the point when the gods rightly honored one who had been seen as contemptible.

sn1.35:6.5.pli: Atha kho tā devatāyo bhiyyoso mattāya ujjhāyantiyo vehāsaṃ abbhuggañchuṃ.
sn1.35:6.5.eng: Then those deities, becoming even more fault-finding, flew up in the air.

sn1.35:7.3.eng: with hidden anger and heavy hate,

sn1.35:8.2.eng: and no-one here had gone astray:

sn1.35:10.4.eng: and that’s who doesn’t go astray.

sn1.35:11.1.eng: If you don’t give your pardon

sn1.35:11.3.eng: with hidden anger and heavy hate,

sn1.35:11.5.eng: I don’t approve of such enmity,

sn1.35:11.6.eng: and so I pardon your mistake.”
